Award.AwardTitle: CPS: Medium: A Cross-Layer Approach to Taming Cyber-Physical Uncertainties in Vehicular Wireless Networking and Platoon Control

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project proposes a cross-layer framework in which vehicular wireless networking and platoon control interact with each other to tame cyber-physical uncertainties. Based on the real-time capacity region of wireless networking and the physical process of vehicle movements, platoon control selects its control strategies and the corresponding requirements on the timeliness and throughput of wireless data delivery to optimize control performance. Based on the requirements from platoon control, wireless networking controls co-channel interference and adapts to cyber-physical uncertainties to ensure the timeliness and throughput of single-hop as well as multi-hop broadcast. For proactively addressing the impact of vehicle mobility on wireless broadcast, wireless networking also leverages input from platoon control on vehicle movement prediction. In realizing the cross-layer framework, wireless scheduling ensures agile, predictable interference control in the presence of cyber-physical uncertainties.

If successful, this project will lead to a general and rigorous framework for wireless vehicular cyber-physical network control that will enable safe, efficient, and clean transportation. The principles and techniques for taming cyber-physical uncertainties will provide insight into other application domains of wireless networked sensing and control such as unmanned aerial vehicles and smart power grids. This project will also develop integrative research and education on wireless cyber-physical systems through multi-level, multi-component educational activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Transforming the traditional, single-vehicle-oriented safety and efficiency control, next-generation vehicles are expected to cooperate with one another and with the transportation infrastructures in ensuring safety, maximizing fuel economy, and minimizing emission and congestion. Two bases of this vision are vehicular wireless networking and networked vehicle control, with the former enabling real-time sensing and control within the ecosystem of vehicles and infrastructures and the latter enabling intelligent actions upon the real-time sensing information across the ecosystem. Subject to complex cyber-physical uncertainties and supporting mission-critical tasks, real-time vehicular wireless networking and networked vehicle control require rethinking the basic assumptions and methodologies for wireless networking and networked control. Within this context, this project has made important progress towards an integrated framework for vehicular wireless control networking and vehicle platoon control.

 

In wireless networking, this project has developed a field-deployable approach to predictable control of wireless interference in data transmission scheduling --- a 40+ years open problem. Based on the novel Physical-Ratio-K (PRK) wireless interference model and innovative protocol mechanisms (e.g., control-theoretic approach to model instantiation and multi-timescale scheduling), the approach transforms the non-local interference control problem into a local control problem, thus enabling agile adaptation to dynamics and uncertainties in vehicular sensing-and-control networks. The approach provides a field-deployable solution to the problem of predictable interference control, which has been open since the very first wireless data network (i.e., the ALOHA network) was invented in 1970s. Predictable interference control as enabled by the approach is a foundation for predictable networked vehicle control as well as the control and networking co-design. The project has also developed innovative approaches to leveraging heterogeneous wireless communication resources and network coding for improved communication capacity and timeliness, and the project has developed spatiotemporal frameworks for reasoning about V2X (e.g., vehicle-to-vehicle, vehicle-to-infrastructure) communication strategies for a wide range of networked vehicle control applications such as active safety control, fuel economy optimization, adaptive vehicle tuning, and traffic-jam assist.

 

Based on predictable V2X communication enabled by the team’s research effort, this project has introduced a weighted and constrained consensus seeking framework for coordinated control of vehicle platoons under realistic communication conditions and constraints. The framework and associated algorithms use only local information as provided by on-board sensors and V2X communication, yet the localized framework and algorithms achieve global convergence to the desired platoon formation, with optimal convergence rate, robustness against sensor noise and communication delays, fast reformation of platoons after vehicle addition and departure, and resilience to communication channel interruptions. Fundamental aspects of such a framework has been developed rigorously, including system identification, state estimation, and discrete-event estimation under quantized observations and irregular/random sampling, asynchronous networked control, and stability of stochastic systems under random delays.  To maximize highway utility while ensuring zero accident, the project has introduced, for the first time, the mean-variance control framework to platoon control.
